spendDelayCards.title: Delay the purchase by 24 hours
spendDelayCards.body: Impulses shrink when you pause. You can always choose later with a clearer head.

spendDelayCards.title: Do a 10-second budget check
spendDelayCards.body: Look at your daily/weekly limit. If you’re unsure, delay the decision.

spendDelayCards.title: Name the impulse (pick one)
spendDelayCards.body: Validation, curiosity, FOMO, anxiety, boredom. Naming reduces its power.

spendDelayCards.title: Close the app right now
spendDelayCards.body: You don’t have to decide while activated. Close the app, then do one tiny action.

copy.failBody: Let’s aim for the next 1-minute win.

motivation_messages: The average person spends 90 minutes a day on dating apps. That time adds up.
Boosts are priced to feel small. Over a month, they add up to real money.
Every urge you resist rewires your brain a little.
Checking for matches releases the same dopamine loop as slot machines.
One pause today trains your brain for an easier pause tomorrow.
Swiping feels productive. It usually isn’t.
The anxiety doesn’t come from not checking. It comes from the habit of checking.
Dating apps are designed to keep you scrolling, not to help you find someone.
The best thing you can do right now is close the app.
A notification is just a notification. You decide what it means.
Urgency is manufactured. Nothing changes if you wait 10 minutes.
Spending money on a boost won’t change how you feel about yourself.
You are not one swipe away from solving loneliness.
The itch to check fades in about 90 seconds if you don’t act on it.
Small consistent choices build bigger changes than big impulsive ones.
Most matches go nowhere. Most sessions waste time. That’s not your fault.
Premium features are priced to exploit the fear of missing out.
Resisting once makes resisting twice easier.
The app wants your attention. You don’t have to give it.
Time offline is time available for things that actually feel good.
Opening the app out of boredom is a habit, not a need.
You can feel the urge and still not act on it. That’s the skill.
Real connection takes time. An app can’t shortcut that.
Every dollar not spent on a boost is a dollar you chose yourself.
Checking for likes late at night never helps you sleep better.
The urge usually peaks quickly and then passes.
Awareness is the first step. Noticing the urge without acting on it is the second.
You built this habit over time. You can change it over time too.
Scrolling when lonely can make loneliness worse, not better.
One minute of breathing beats one hour of scrolling.
Your worth is not determined by match count or message reply rates.
A quiet evening without the app is still a good evening.
The longer you wait, the weaker the urge gets.
